title: Islamic Philosophy & Sufism: Al-Ghazali, Ibn Arabi & Averroes
description: The philosophical and mystical traditions of Islam: Al-Ghazali's integration of philosophy and Sufism, Ibn Arabi's visionary metaphysics, and Averroes' Aristotelian commentaries that influenced medieval Europe.
keyFigures: Al-Ghazali (1058-1111): Most influential Islamic theologian, integrated Sufism with orthodox theology
Ibn Arabi (1165-1240): 'Greatest Master' of Sufi metaphysics, doctrine of Unity of Being
Averroes (1126-1198): Leading Aristotelian commentator, major influence on medieval Christian Scholasticism
researchValue: Al-Ghazali's 'Deliverance from Error' describes his spiritual crisis and turn to Sufism. Ibn Arabi's mystical poetry with esoteric commentary. Averroes' Aristotelianism sparked debates in medieval Europe about faith and reason.
